fields.prompt:

var colors = {

  "azure": "#f0ffff",

  "black": "#000000",

  "blue": "#0000ff",
  "blueviolet": "#8a2be2",

}

fields.prompt: According to the video which is the most preferred way to include JS in a HTML file?
fields.options: ["To write the JS code within the body section of the HTML document", "To include it inside the <script> tag of the head section of the document", "To add it in a separate file and refer to it with a <link> tag in the head section", "To add it in a separate file and refer to it with a <script> tag in the head section", "All of the above options are equally preferable"]

fields.prompt:
```javascript
<button>Print</button>
```

Rewrite the statement above so that whenever this button is clicked, the document prints the word "Printed" in the console.

fields.prompt:
```html
<html>
    <head>
        <title>Sample Document</title>
        <script></script>
    </head>
    <body>
        <input onchange="recordChange()" />
    </body>
</html>
```

The HTML document above will result in an error. Why?
fields.options: ["The script tag is empty", "Because recordChange function does not take any parameters", "Because recordChange function has not been defined anywhere", "The document does not import any external JS file"]
fields.searchField:
```html
<html>
    <head>
        <title>sample document</title>
        <script></script>
    </head>
    <body>
        <input onchange="recordchange()" />
    </body>
</html>
```

the html document above will result in an error. why?

fields.prompt:
```html
<input onchange="document.write("Input Changed")" />
```

The statement above is correct and will print "Input Changed" to the document every time the input changes. True or False?
fields.options: ["True, because we are using the onchange event and inside the value, we are using document.write method.", "False, because we need to use console.log for this statement to work properly.", "True, because onchange method can only be used for input, and not for button", "False, because you cannot write the value of an attribute inside double quotes and then also use double quotes within the value"]
fields.searchField:
```html
<input onchange="document.write("input changed")" />
```

the statement above is correct and will print "input changed" to the document every time the input changes. true or false?

fields.prompt:
```html
div.appendChild(paragraph)
```

Assuming that the variable "div" contains a div element and the variable "paragraph" contains a paragraph element, what would the above statement result in?

**Hint** - If you are doubtful, it is always advisable to test out the scenario in a codepen before choosing an answer, for best chances of getting this right.
fields.options: ["It will place the paragraph element after the div element", "It will place the paragraph element inside the div element at the end", "It will place the paragraph element inside the div element at the very beginning of the div element", "It will place the paragraph element ahead of the div element", "The line will result in an error"]
fields.searchField:
```html
div.appendchild(paragraph)
```

assuming that the variable "div" contains a div element and the variable "paragraph" contains a paragraph element, what would the above statement result in?

**hint** - if you are doubtful, it is always advisable to test out the scenario in a codepen before choosing an answer, for best chances of getting this right.

fields.prompt:
Create a new pen on Codepen and with just JS, achieve the following tasks:-
1. Add a button to your HTML page with the label 'Button'
2. To that button, add an event listener that shows an alert box with the message "Mouse moved over button" whenever the mouse moves over the button. 
3. After the alert box has been shown 3 times, stop showing the alert box. This means that once the alert box has been shown 3 times, it should no longer show even when the mouse moves over the button. 
4. Make sure that you are not using any HTML!


Once you have written the code, save the pen and copy the link and paste it below.

**Hint** - Think about how you can keep count of the number of times that the method has been executed. Start with the following code:-

```javascript
var body = document.body
var count = 0 // this keeps track of the number of times that the alert box has been displayed
```
fields.searchField:
create a new pen on codepen and with just js, achieve the following tasks:-
1. add a button to your html page with the label 'button'
2. to that button, add an event listener that shows an alert box with the message "mouse moved over button" whenever the mouse moves over the button. 
3. after the alert box has been shown 3 times, stop showing the alert box. this means that once the alert box has been shown 3 times, it should no longer show even when the mouse moves over the button. 
4. make sure that you are not using any html!


once you have written the code, save the pen and copy the link and paste it below.

**hint** - think about how you can keep count of the number of times that the method has been executed. start with the following code:-

```javascript
var body = document.body
var count = 0 // this keeps track of the number of times that the alert box has been displayed
```
